title: 109_s1260
content: The Act titled "Common Sense Indian Gambling Reform Act of 2005" requires consultation with state, local, and tribal governments. Section 20 of the Indian Gaming Regulatory Act (25 U.S.C. 2719) is amended to include specific criteria for Indian tribes in Oklahoma regarding land reservations and trust status. The Indian Gaming Regulatory Act is amended to include exceptions for Indian lands in Oklahoma, allowing for gaming establishments after consultation with relevant authorities within 60 miles. The Indian Gaming Regulatory Act is amended to allow gaming establishments on Indian lands in Oklahoma, with conditions that it benefits the tribe, has no negative economic impact within 60 miles, and requires state approval. The Common Sense Indian Gambling Reform Act of 2005 requires state approval for gaming activities on Indian lands, with conditions that the land is within the tribe's primary location and has a significant historical connection to the tribe. The Indian tribe must have a geographic, social, and historical connection to land owned by or held in trust for the tribe, within designated geographical areas for financial assistance and social services, including reservations. The Indian tribe must have a geographic, social, and historical connection to land within designated geographical areas for financial assistance and social services, including reservations. The tribe's designated geographical area is determined during the Federal acknowledgment process, where more than 50 percent of the members reside in a group composed exclusively or almost exclusively of tribe members. The land must be located within the historical residence area of the tribe as determined by the Secretary, or in a State other than Oklahoma within the tribe's boundaries. The Indian tribe must have a historical connection to land within designated geographical areas for financial assistance and social services. Gaming activities must be conducted on 1 contiguous parcel of Indian lands. SEC. 3. TRIBAL GAMING ORDINANCES. Section 11 of the Indian Gaming Regulatory Act (25 U.S.C. 2710) is amended to specify conditions for conducting class II gaming on Indian lands or lands taken into trust for the benefit of Indian tribes. The Indian tribe requested that the land be taken into trust for the purpose of conducting class II gaming activities. Amendments were made to specify conditions for conducting such gaming on Indian lands or lands taken into trust for tribes. Amendments were made to specify conditions for conducting class III gaming activities on Indian lands or lands taken into trust for tribes. The Indian tribe requested that the land be taken into trust for the purpose of conducting class III gaming activities. The definition of "State" was clarified to include the Governor and legislative body. SEC. 4. INVESTIGATION AND APPROVAL. The Chairman and Commission of the Indian Gaming Regulatory Act have powers to approve or disapprove individuals or entities with the highest financial interest in gaming activities. The Commission must identify these entities and conduct background investigations. The Indian Gaming Regulatory Act empowers the Commission to identify and investigate the top 10 persons or entities with the highest financial interest in gaming activities. Background investigations are conducted on these individuals and any other deemed necessary by the Commission. Additionally, tribal gaming ordinances mandate background checks on tribal gaming commissioners. The Indian Gaming Regulatory Act empowers the Commission to conduct background investigations on key individuals involved in tribal gaming, including tribal gaming commissioners, key employees, management officials, and gaming enterprise employees. The Commission's funding is increased from $8,000,000 to $16,000,000. The Indian Gaming Regulatory Act is amended to require Indian tribes to submit an environmental impact statement and obtain the Secretary's consent before using Indian lands for gaming. Existing compacts or agreements related to gaming regulation are not affected by this Act.
